participants.participant: Friedrich Lauer, Vice President, Head of Investor Relations
Dieter Zetsche, Chairman, Head of Mercedes-Benz Cars

plist.p: Welcome to the Global Conference Call of Daimler. At our customer's request, this conference will be recorded. You can listen to the replay by dialing the numbers you will find on the invitation. The replay of the conference call will also be available as audio webcast on demand in the Investor Relations section of the Daimler website.
May I now hand over to Mr. Friedrich Lauer, Head of Daimler Investor Relations. Thank you very much.

Good afternoon from Stuttgart, this is Friedrich Lauer from Daimler Investor Relations. On behalf of Daimler, I would like to welcome you on both the telephone and the Internet to our full-year results call.

We are happy to have with us today the Chairman of the Board of Management of Daimler and Head of Mercedes Benz Cars, Dr. Dieter Zetsche; the Head of Daimler Trucks, Andreas Renschler; and the Chief Financial Officer, Bodo Uebber. In order to give you maximum time for your questions, Dr. Dieter and Mr. Uebber will begin the conference with a short introduction which will be directly followed by a Q&A session. A webcast and all the charts of the press conference held this morning are available on our website.

Before we start, I have the usual administrative details. I would like to remind you that this teleconference is governed by the Safe Harbor wording that you'll find in our published results documents.

Please note that our presentations contain forward-looking statements that reflect management's current views with respect to future events. These forward-looking statements can be identified by expressions such as assume, anticipate, believe, estimate, expect, intend, may, plan, project, or should. Such statements are subject to risks and uncertainties, examples of which are set out in the Safe Harbor wording in our documents and are also described in our most recent Form 20-F under the heading Risk Factors. If the assumptions underlying any of these statements prove incorrect, then actual results maybe materially different from those expressed or implied by such statements. Forward-looking statements speak only to the date on which they are made.
Now I would like to hand over the conference to Dr. Zetsche.

Gentleman – new attempt, thanks Friedrich. Ladies and gentleman, for us 2007 was a crucial year that set our course for the future. We clearly defined our strategic focus within the group and in our in our businesses. We sold our majority share in Chrysler and that significantly reduced our risk exposure. We set ambitious financial goals for all of our business operations. We substantially improved our profitability. We made considerable progress on the road to sustainable mobility. We made our organization faster and more empowered. We further optimized our net assets by selling real estate holdings, and finally we laid the foundation for a high performance culture.

Our EBIT was significantly higher than in 2006 and higher than our target of at least €8.5 billion. Despite the financial burdens associated with the de-merger from Chrysler, our net profit was higher than in the previous year. This shows just how much we've improved our operations. We will share our successes with our shareholders. We propose paying out a dividend of €2 per share for 2007. That's an increase of one-third over the previous year. At the same we continue our share buyback program as of today. We have a successful year behind us, and we're optimistic that despite some difficult market conditions, the year ahead will be successful too because all of our business operations are running well.

At Mercedes-Benz Cars, we sold a record number of vehicles despite a difficult market environment. At the same time, we significantly increased our return on sales to 9.1%. We aim to do even better in the future by achieving the average return on sales of 10% by 2010 at the latest.

We continued to improve our productivity. In 2006, we increased productivity by 12% and last year we improved it by another 10%. In the coming years, we will continue the improvements by an additional 10 to 15% depending on the model series. We plan to expand on a regional basis and to continuously further improve our product quality. We aim to appeal to our customers' emotions and we have got the right products for that, both on the road and in the pipeline.

In the next two years, we are going to launch a whole series of new products. In 2008 alone, we will introduce two new and six updated models to the market. At Daimler Trucks, we proved that our management of market cycles works. For the first time ever in a downturn market and in spite of dramatic market declines in the US and Japan, our truck division not only stayed profitable, but even exceeded last year's good result with an EBIT of €2.1 billion and a return on sales of 7.5%. This success was mainly due to the outstanding results posted by Mercedes-Benz Trucks whose business in Europe and Latin America further improved to excellent levels. That's another reason why we've raised our return on sales target from 7 to 8% starting 2010 as an average across the market cycle for Trucks. We aim to achieve this goal through the consistent continuation of our Global Excellence Program. The big highlight in 2008 will be the new Actros, our flagship model, and also the best selling heavy-duty truck in Europe. To sum things up, Daimler Trucks is right on track.

At Mercedes-Benz Vans, we set a new sales record in 2007 and significantly increased our profitability. High demand for the Sprinter has led to full utilization of our production capacity. We will further enhance our Van production efficiency in 2008. At the same time, we'll also expand our production capacity.

Daimler Buses once again posted increased sales and set a benchmark for profitability. We plan to maintain this position by continuing our product offensive in Europe, strengthening our position in growth markets, and further consolidating our leadership in Alternative Drive Systems.
Let me add here that both Vans and Buses generated considerably higher earnings in 2007 compared to the previous year.

Daimler Financial Services posted a 4.8 return on equity in spite of the high cost of building up a new NAFTA organization, a move that was necessary after the separation from Chrysler Financial. On the whole, our Financial Services business is also developing in a stable and positive manner. What's more, our proven risk management system will ensure that this remains the case despite the current market turbulences.

The Financial Services business still offers promising growth opportunities, for example in the insurance and fleet management sectors. Daimler Financial Services, therefore, remains a key pillar of our growth strategy. This brief overview shows that we've achieved a great deal at the group level and in each of our business areas. Still it is clear that we cannot and will not simply sit back and relax. That's why we are confident with regard to our business developments in 2008 and the following years. At Mercedes-Benz Cars, we aim to top the sales record we set in 2007. At Daimler Trucks, we expect to see increasing sales in North America. We aim to slightly increase our sales in Europe, Latin America and Asia. For Mercedes-Benz Vans we anticipate a continued rise in unit sales while for Daimler Buses, we expect unit sales to remain stable overall.

What will this mean for our earnings? At Mercedes-Benz Cars and Daimler Trucks, we expect to further increase our earnings. At Financial Services, we are confident that this year we can once again achieve an average return on equity of at least 14%. In line with expectation of our divisions, we anticipate that Daimler Group's EBIT for 2008 from ongoing operations will clearly exceed the levels reached in 2007. The results for 2007 included income from the transfer of shares in EADS and financial burdens due to Chrysler and NMM.

Overall we aim to achieve a 9% average return on sales in our automotive business across our market and product cycles from 2010 at the latest. Of course, we know that the global economic environment has become more difficult and we are aware of the related risks. Nonetheless we expect to achieve our goals because we have the right strategy, because we have the operational strength we need, and because our position in the Financial Services business is adequately conservative. We will further intensify our efforts in safety and sustainable mobility. That's why Daimler will once again move forward in 2008.
And now I would like to hand over to Bodo Uebber. I look forward to our discussions later on. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Dieter. Ladies and gentlemen, Dieter Zetsche has briefly explained to you last year's business development of each of our divisions and our outlook for the future. I would now like to focus on the key figures of our financial statements, which are preliminary and not yet audited. Daimler's EBIT, which solely reflects the continuing operations, increased compared to the prior year by a substantial 3.7 billion to €8.7 billion. So we surpassed our announced goal of at least 8.5 billion although we had to accept charges from Chrysler and EADS in the fourth quarter.

Net profit improved by 5% to €4 billion, it includes charges of €2.2 billion related to the Chrysler transaction. In terms of our continuing activities, we increased net profit by €1.7 billion to €4.9 billion. We can also report today on very solid results for the free cash flow of the industrial business at €7.6 billion, and for the net liquidity of the industrial business of €12.9 billion.

Our balance sheet is extremely strong as indicated by an equity ratio of more than 40% for our industrial business. Our cost liquidity of €17.1 billion was at an extremely high level as a result of transferring the refinancing of our Financial Services business to Cerberus. We will continue reducing it this year by repaying mature liabilities and through our share buyback program.

This also applies to the net liquidity of the industrial business. In the medium term, we want to further optimize our capital structure. For this reason, we initiated a share buyback program in August 2007. In this context, we announced that we would apply € 7.5 billion to buyback up to 10% of our own shares. Between the end of August and the middle of 2007, we acquired 50 million shares worth €3.5 billion. These shares were canceled by the end of the year. We will resume the share buyback program already today. The program is based on the retained earnings in the parent company's financial statements, which amounted to €3.5 billion at the end of 2006, which were used to buyback shares in 2007.

In the financial statements for 2007, Daimler AG we reported net profit of €12.4 billion. As allowed by the German Stock Corporation Act, the Board of Management and the Supervisory Board, we'll transfer half of that to retained earnings. This is equivalent to €6.2 billion. After deducting the proposed dividend of €2 billion, an amount of €4.2 billion remains. With the approval of the shareholders at the Annual Meeting in April, we will transfer this amount to retained earnings as well. This will provide us with sufficient resources to buyback more shares.

The very high net profit of Daimler AG is a result on the one hand of the good business development, and Mercedes-Benz Cars and Daimler Trucks. On the other hand, the parent company received dividend payouts from its foreign subsidiaries. In addition, we realized gains on the sale of EADS shares and on the transfer of investments.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your attention. We will now be glad to answer your questions.

Thank you very much Dr. Zetsche and Mr. Uebber. Ladies and gentlemen, you may ask your questions now. I will identify the questionnaire by name, but please also introduce yourself with your name and the name of the organization that you're representing before asking your questions. Two practical points, firstly please avoid using a mobile phone, as this disturbs the quality of the call for everyone, and secondly please ask your question in English. Before we start the session, the Operator will explain the procedure.
Thank you.
Okay. We'll take the first question today from John Lawson please.

Thanks, good afternoon, John Lawson from Citi. Two points if I may, firstly you've included Vans and Buses I think in auto margins target for the first time. I guess there are some of us out here who've tried to deconstruct the Van, Bus, and Other segment. And know how difficulty it is to tease-out underlying Van and Bus profit numbers, at least it was in 2007. So can you put us out of our misery please and reveal the '07 margin performance of Vans and Buses? That's the first question. Second one is that I noticed the R&D capitalization is going up, but the amortization is flat or even going slightly down. I mean are you entering a phase where capitalization is going to be much higher? I think in the past, this hasn't seemed to be something that was on the horizon for you. Thanks.

John, to your first question, our policy is to disclose the segment profitabilities on the one hand that is Mercedes-Benz Cars and on the another hand, it is Daimler Trucks, and then Financial Services, and the so-called VBO segment, which is Van, Bus and Others. I do accept that it is difficult to extract the profitability of the two – of Van and Buses. As we've already said we will think about a disclosure change during the course of the year, especially related to Vans and Bus. So in this regard, you don't see this number exactly. We have in our automotive target which Dieter Zetsche this morning explained we have summarized Mercedes-Benz Cars, Daimler Trucks, the Van and the Bus business, which amounts to roughly 8% in the actuals of 2007. And if you make the equation of the revenues in this amount which is roughly 13.5 billion. You get to a somewhat average margin for the Van and Bus business.
Okay.

When it comes to the – your second question of the R&D capitalization, yes it is right that we have an increase in capitalization ratios which are roughly right now 27, 25% in both businesses. That holds true for Daimler Trucks and also for Mercedes-Benz Cars, and which relates to certain project of course and timings. And that was an increase compared to 2005 and 2006. And I expect this number to slightly increase further during the course of the next years. And Dieter Zetsche already said this morning that we have also in the R&D sector due to the investments we need to do for CO2 and other related technologies, an increase in R&D of maximum 1% of revenues in MBC.
I think it's fair to say that even with that slight increase we are at the low end of the spectrum of our peers.
This is absolutely right. All our peers are north or far north of 30%, so we are in this regard, absolutely right, very conservative so to say.
And that 1% increase is based on the cash R&D spend I take it?
That 1% is based on the cash R&D, right.
Thank you.
The next question from Jurgen Geiger please.

Yes, good afternoon. I have three questions, if I may. Dr. Zetsche, with regards to the 10% average Mercedes target, you're with the company now since 30 years. And I think it's fair to say that Mercedes has never delivered such performance. Could you maybe share with us the main thoughts, what has changed at Mercedes that you think that we are seeing such a structural uplift in average margins for Mercedes? Second, with regards to Trucks, we all noticed you lifted your target to 8% average EBIT margin. I wonder whether you could share also your thoughts here. Why you do that at that point in time especially once the market is worrying about certainly more difficult economic environment. And lastly with regards to Chrysler, could you clarify the situation in the event that Chrysler LLC would require further money, can they bank on Daimler, or can they not bank on Daimler? Thank you.

As far as the first question is concerned, I am glad that you didn't ask why we don't go for 20% or 30%, but for 10%. I agree with your assessment that looking to our peers and to our history, it's an ambitious target we are setting ourselves. My assessment is that in the past as today, we were striving for superior vehicles, success with our customers, and we were successful in this regard. We were less focused on operational excellence. I think that is a fact. And with a very strong focus on the one hand continuing to benefit from the high revenues per unit based on our good customer base, which we're enjoying. Hence, now on the other hand, the strive for benchmark position in our cost position, we opened this possibility of margins of 10%. We will face and we're already facing significant challenges not just from exchange rates and raw materials like anybody else, but certainly from the CO2 challenge as well. We are aware of that, and we have some homework to do in order to deliver on the CO2 challenge and at the same time maintain margins of 10% as promised. But we feel confident that we will be able to solve that request.
Let me jump to the Chrysler question because afterwards I would relate to Andreas because of course this target hasn't come from me, but it's his own assessment of his business I guess.

Chrysler LLC, we have a clear contract and which are defining the transaction. You know the commitments, which are included in those contracts as far as warranties or guarantees are concerned, or our pension funds, other issues. They are all transparent and public. Other than that, there are no obligations, legal or moral from Daimler towards Chrysler. Andreas?

Let me take your question. Why are we now increasing our average profitability target to 8%? As you know, we said we are striving for the bigger than 7%. But we also said that last year we will have for the first time kind of proof of our strategy managing the cycles because as you know we had a downturn in the United States of – in the Class 8 of over 40%. Like we always said and also in Japan, we had a minus of 25%. Despite this downturn, we were able to deliver profitability, and as Dieter Zetsche mentioned today in the morning, all our divisions also in North America and Asia were positive profitable wise. So that makes us very confident that we can now achieve what we always have said. And that was the reason that we said, now it's time to think where we are, what is the potential with all of the on going projects. And we said okay, it looks that we are now much more confident to go to the 8%.
Thank you.
Max Warburton, you're now next on the list please. Max Warburton, please.
Hello, can you hear me?
We can hear you very well.

Okay, great, thank you. Just two questions please. On the 2007 financials, I think one of interesting things is just how low both the CapEx spend for the Group is and the depreciation charge for the Group once we ex out Chrysler. And I think what a lot of us are wondering is have you found some sort of new approach versus your peers? I mean you talked earlier about R&D, but in your approach versus your peers in running CapEx and depreciation at such low levels, depreciation looks like its 2.5% of Group revenues. Is this level sustainable? And given some of the talk of an extra small car plant in East Europe etcetera, what sort of CapEx number and depreciation figure as a percentage of sales should we be thinking about long-term? That's the first question. And then the second question comes back to Jurgen Geiger's question on Chrysler. Dr. Zetsche, you said that Daimler has no legal or moral responsibility. But could you say categorically, could you, I think you said this last year on the legal side, could you just say there is absolutely no circumstances in which Daimler would put in any extra debt guarantees or funding into Chrysler in the coming years? I think that would be very helpful for all of us. Thanks.

Coming to your second question, I can answer that question being asked by everyone of the following colleagues of yours with a clear, yes, there are no further augments or anything. Was that clear enough?
That's helpful, and on the depreciation and CapEx side?

Let me just make one comment and then hand over to Bodo. The one comment is that or two comments. The first one is that doing the core program, and in the same sense, the supplies for Trucks as well, we have certainly improved our efficiency of capital investments as well, so we are getting more out of less. But on the Mercedes side, in accordance with the even further increased activities regarding CO2 emission reductions, we see the possibility of an increase of the CapEx rate for Mercedes of up to 1 percentage point. Very much similar to the FE rate or ratio which might see a similar increase of up to 1 percentage point. That's of course built into our plans for the next three years within our operative planning, and not a surprise. But talking about the absolute levels, Bodo will come back to you right away.

So for the CapEx, we have talked about the R&D ratio, for the CapEx ratio, the situation will be somewhat the same. In 2007, we had a 3.6% CapEx ratio for Mercedes-Benz Cars. And that will go up in 2008 and 9 with 1%. Ratio on the Group level, it will be somewhat the same. Within Trucks, it is based on next year, next year we will see the kind of peak in investments due to the investments in medium duty engine and the future platform of trucks. And then it will go down again, so overall we will see in '08 a 1% increase. For the depreciation, the effect which we have seen this year is based on our – that we use our production tooling and architectures for two platforms or longer, which is a decrease. It will certainly, by the CapEx and the other stuff, also somewhat increase in the future.

Okay, thank you. Actually, can I just have one follow up question on Chrysler, and it's nothing contentious at all. It's just looking at your guidance, you're saying you expect to post EBIT from continuing operations well above the prior year level. But obviously at the moment, we have Chrysler in the reported operating profit, I think that might move, but we are going to have 20% of Chrysler's loss. I mean do you have any ability to forecast how much Chrysler will lose in '08? I mean what kind of guidance can you give us, what would your advice be to analysts in terms of trying to forecast what that equity loss will be in the accounts this year and going forward, that would be really helpful? Thanks.
I would say even if we could do that, and we can't, we shouldn't do that because I think it is not our task to report about Chrysler's financial performance.
Okay. But I do understand your guidance correctly, which is – it's just, there is no EPS guidance because we don't know what that's going to be. We can only really talk about the current operations?
Our guidance is our guidance as we have set it.
Okay. Thanks very much.
Okay. Next question from Adam Jonas please.

Hi, thanks. Good evening, Adam Jonas, Morgan Stanley. Two questions on the Financial Services business. First, can you quantify the magnitude of the organizational change costs at Financial Services? It still looks like it's weighing on the fourth quarter. Can you give us an idea of when that starts to alleviate in terms of whether Q1, we can start to see a step change? We understand there is a lot going on there, but it does appear to be still depressing the profit there. And also can you disclose the risk loss ratio that you have on Mercedes and/or Trucks? So if you could be specific, the global risk loss ratio that you're provisioning for now and how that increased or presumably increased from '06. And if you can give us a bit of detail in terms of quarter-by-quarter because I understand you view these things on quarterly basis, what the trend has been towards the latter part of 2007? Thanks very much.

So, Adam, hello Adam. So only a few questions you have. Regarding the Financial Services business of course we had in 2007 separation effects, de-merger effects, especially in the third and the first quarter. We have made the legal separation in August. We have made the – we've applied for licensees in October, which we've gotten. Now we can do our own business so to say on, but we're using the systems, the IT system and some transition service level agreements from Chrysler Financial. This we will separate in mid of April. So we will have these impacts in the first and the second quarter in minimum and of course in parallel we will look for measures how to get back to our number one position in terms of efficiency. So that will be then an ongoing task. So at minimum, the expenses related to this subject will occur in the first and the second quarters.

Then your questions regarding the cost of risk and delinquency development in 2007, that was pretty much related to the last quarter. We have slightly upward trends in this aspect. On the one hand in the Mercedes-Benz passenger car business, but also in the Truck business that reflects not that we are in subprime to say that clearly. But of course, the cooling down of the industry has its impact also on our risk ratios slightly and we are far away from the long-term average trends, which we have seen in the past.
Wait a minute. Does that – sorry just to clarify, does that imply that you are far away from average trends that you're still below the long-term average trends?
Yes...
And you're coming out from a good level.
Oh yeah.
Much better.
Much better yes.
Many of your competitors actually disclosed the basis point risk loss, can you do that same please?
I will think about it.
It would be very, very helpful, especially given the concerns in the market. I think many of your investors would appreciate it. I'm sure it's very low.
Yeah, thank you for the...
Thank you.
Okay, next question from Arndt Ellinghorst please.

Yeah, thanks. It's Arndt Ellinghorst from Credit Suisse. A question on CO2. I mean there is a lot of talk now about the R&D cost impact from the CO2 issue. I guess we sit probably next year together and talk about the material cost impact, that it takes from adding all the different technologies to become more fuel efficient finally. Could you share some of your views regarding the costs associated really from adopting new technologies to make your engines more fuel efficient? It would be an assumption of something between 30 to €40 per gram per car, an assumption that we could take, firstly?

And secondly, on your revenues per unit at Mercedes in the final quarter of last year, I think it dropped by roughly 12% on the back of increased C Class and smart sales and also currency. Could you share some of your views regarding contribution margin on the products that you're newly launching? And I guess we were told earlier that material – that cost of producing the new C-Class is something 20 to 25% below the old version. Could you give us some light for your new products moving forward and also the new E-Class next year?

As far as CO2 is concerned, I consider it impossible to give you a euro per gram indication because these costs are progressive. What that means is that the first gram is almost for free, and the next five grams are costing something, and the next grams are more expensive, and the last grams are the most expensive one. So which just means that you can work on just a better energy management. And then you can come to things like start/stop or low-resistance tires, and then you go on to direct injection second generation for gasoline engines, and turbochargers and ultimately end up with a hybrid component. And all of these units have progressive cost per fuel saving. And therefore, it very much depends on the final definition of the legislation, and that's not the only requirement. On top of that, we have the CO2 taxes with different limitations and different countries, we have metropolitan areas and all of that. But at the end of the day, it very much depends on how far you have to go to define the average cost you have to add to the variable of your vehicles. And therefore, we just can't give you a more precise answer before we know what we finally have to do. But of course, we have very clear ideas if the average has to go to X, and this is what we have to spend, when it goes to Y, that's what we have to do then.

But I think it's fair to say what you said that by this time next year we have much more transparent discussions just because we know the framework much better. As far as the average revenues per unit is concerned, you mentioned some of the impacts, you did not mention some others. And significant one for instance being used car sales, especially in the fourth quarter of 2006. We very much cleared out a significant inventory of used cars, which we didn't have to do this year because we were at historically low levels. So that reduction in revenues, if you want, which you then divide by the new car sales even though they have nothing to do with it, then we have different levels of leasing ratios. In leasing, obviously we get only about a third depending on how long it is, a third of the revenues. And if this share increases, then the revenues per unit go down. So there are multiple effects structurally we have not seen a significant deterioration of our mix in new car sales altogether. Just say, Bodo is showing figures to me...

No, no, no, but year-over-year if you look at the year-over-year development, it's not minus 12%, it's minus 1%. And that reflects what Dieter Zetsche said, currency, used car, and also the leasing penetration. And then it fluctuates sometimes in the quarters.

Now as far as the new C-Class is concerned, it's always important what you relate to. When we for instance look at the cost of the last generation C-Class when we introduced it. And then at the time when we decided about the successor model, at that time we defined a certain amount of cost reduction for the new model, which was very, very significant. But till the launch of the new model, we significantly reduced the cost of the old model through the core program and other aspects. So that at the time of launch the cost reduction from the old to the new model was lower than at the time of the decision. But in any case, the new model is meeting and exceeding our margin objectives we have set with this project. And therefore, we're very satisfied with accomplishments in this regard. And the same from today's perspective will apply to the new E-Class where we will see a significant improvement in the cost position as well.

And if I – thank you very much. If I just may clarify on the CO2 issue, I mean you're sitting on the Board of the VDA of also within ACEA. Would it be fair to say that the industry so far has no real clue about the technology costs associated that are coming up within the next three or four years?

No, I don't think that this is a fair assessment. We know exactly what those different components to the extent they are developed today are costing today. We have relatively good understanding what kind of cost reduction based on volume, based on further optimization can be accomplished within the next 3, 4, 5 years for those components. But as I said before, we don't know exactly how far we have to go in introducing expensive technologies. Of course, we try to get as far as possible with more cost efficient technologies, but not knowing the final legislation we don't know how far we have to go.

I mean just to give you an idea when you talk about the hybridization of a product, you definitely talk about values which are somewhere, assuming that by higher volume and so on, you get scale effects when things are going down, something from 4,000 upwards euro per unit. So if you were to assume you would have to add that to every single unit, it's not difficult to calculate the effect. If you have to do that for 5% of the fleet, obviously you have the different impact. So those questions are more relevant than the question of whether it's 4,500 or €5,000 per unit. But our clear intention is on the one hand to use the most cost efficient technologies possibly, secondly to make the technologies we're working on more cost efficient than they are today. Thirdly, to leverage further productivity and efficiency potentials, which we have in our overall system, in order to offset cost increases coming from that source. And ultimately, to add something to our price tag at least based on the financial benefit over the life cycle the customer gains by a more fuel-efficient vehicle.
Thank you very much.
The next question from Philippe Houchois please.

Yes, good afternoon, Philippe Houchois from JPMorgan. I have two questions, the first one for Mr. Renschler. Six to nine months ago he was focused so much on Fuso, and no one talks about it anymore. Could you update us on the progress in the division in Japan as well because we had some surprisingly good GDP numbers recently? And if you're happy with the progress on that business as a continuing part of the Group?

And Dr. Zetsche, if I could get more of a general answer from you, philosophically there has been a lot of noise recently about special DV versus current DV, and you have chosen to increase the current dividend. Can you give us what's your priority between share buyback, special dividend, current dividend as your preferred way of returning cash? And also if we're still looking at, you know, down the road, a benchmark of a payout ratio of around 40% which is what the DAX is telling us right now, I think Mr. Uebber had given us that number. Thank you.

You know, I'm starting with Fuso. So I will be sure that we are still working very intensively with Fuso and it's still on our attention. The progress was last year very good. I think despite the issue we had in the Japanese domestic market, the home market, it's minus 25%. We overcome this, Fuso was overall profitable and we had a good increase in the international market. So overall, basic sales volume could also increase slightly. So overall, we are working in the process, the integration comes further. As you know, if we are, when we started with Fuso and we said, okay, we have changed to put commonality parts around the world, including Fuso. We always said it needs time. So now we have the heavy-duty engine as one of the good examples we will launch this year or we will see it on the road this year in April with our customers at Freightliner, and step-by-step we will do the same with Fuso. So, we are very good, let's say we made good improvement last year. And we are on our track and our plans are coming through that Fuso will be a very good part of our overall global truck organization.

As far as dividends and other shareholder measures are concerned. I think we have to differentiate between two elements. One is the ongoing business with high margins and good cash flow. In this regard, we have made the statement that we want to be at benchmark levels of the return from these ongoing profits to our shareholders, and this is a dividend obviously. And secondly, there is the current situation of high net liquidity, and a non-leverage situation, where we have said that we want to develop our capital structure into a slightly leveraged capital structure, not the least looking at our cost of capital, the WACC, as a consequence.
